Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Medium: Self-Care Management: Patient-Centered Diabetic Wound Care Using Smart Phones

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project addresses specific health challenges of patients with diabetic foot ulcers and focuses on two key challenges: automatically analyzing wound healing progress of patients with diabetic foot ulcers, and using technology to motivate these patients to better care for their wounds and their diabetes. The proposed smart phone application requires the development of image analysis algorithms and is patient-centered and aims to improve patient health and wellbeing in a patient population that is experiencing severe and expensive health problems.

In the performance of this work, the project extends the medical education of students to include how state-of-the-art computing technologies can assist healing. This research is of societal importance and provides technology-enabled care for patients with advanced problems like diabetic foot ulcers. Furthermore, it improves the quality of lives and reduces health care costs. Finally, the cross-disciplinary research team broadly disseminates results to multiple disciplines and is quite diverse. The team's diversity and the societal value of a health care application are helpful in recruiting a diverse group of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research developed a smart phone application, called Sugar. Sugar helps patients monitor their diabetes and diabetic foot ulcers, by providing them with data regarding their wound size and wound healing as well as instant feedback pertaining to behavioral aspects of disease management, and by encouraging them to engage in activities that will improve their well-being. The app supports those patients in more advanced stages of type 2 diabetes, where diabetic foot ulcers are a serious and expensive problem. Sugar is patient-centered and has an intuitive and easy-to-use interface appropriate for patients with diabetic foot ulcers (elderly and possibly vision impaired). This research is joint work of Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) and University of Massachusetts Medical School (UMMS). The app was successfully evaluated for usability by patients of UMMS’s wound clinic who used the app for six-weeks. 

Developing Sugar involved two technical challenges. First, this research created Wound Image Analysis Algorithms, which compute the healing progress of diabetic foot ulcers from pictures taken by patients using a standard smartphone camera and a foot box to control distance and lighting. These computations automatically find the wound in the picture, determine wound area and wound tissue types based on color, and using these two measures, calculate a healing score. The algorithms are able to execute on a standard smartphone in just a few seconds, something that has not been done before. The algorithms can also compare a wound image to previous images of the same wound, recognizing when the wound is getting better or getting worse. We also developed more advanced algorithms that produce improved results in wound area detection and segmentation into wound tissue types. These advanced algorithms, however, are more computationally intensive and require a laptop computer with more computing power. This additional computing power is helpful when wounds are on the edge of a foot or are of irregular shape.

Second, the research investigated Feedback to Patients that would help them better manage their diabetes and engage in healthy behaviors. To meet this behavioral health objective, the app provides timely, patient-tailored messages that suggest meaningful and actionable feedback about wound and diabetic health. Patients input their glucose levels and weight via a Bluetooth glucometer and wireless weight scale that automatically send the results to the app. Patients can also manually enter their physical activity and mood. The app responds with encouraging messages based on the input provided. The app also shows graphs of glucose, weight, and activity levels. It produces a daily report, a daily health tip, and a weekly report of diabetic health. The messages to patients are based on suggestions from focus groups of patients as well as the behavioral literature on managing health.

Intellectual Merit: Development of image processing algorithms that are powerful enough to detect wound area/size and healing progress and efficient enough to run on a smartphone was a major accomplishment, which has potentially broader impacts for other medical conditions beyond diabetes. Development of a mobile app that helps patients manage their type 2 diabetes and provides clinically sound feedback to support behavior change and that the patients find easy to use and useful was another important accomplishment.

Broader Impacts: The Sugar app addresses a growing and expensive health problem, type 2 diabetes and associated foot wounds. This research is of societal importance because technology-enabled care for patients with advanced problems like diabetic foot ulcers can improve the quality of their lives as well as reduce healthcare costs. This project provided educational opportunities to WPI undergraduate and graduate students who worked on it, as well as to medical residents at UMMS who worked with the patients using the smartphone. The image processing algorithms developed have been integrated into computer science courses at WPI. Finally, the interdisciplinary team of researchers from multiple disciplines at WPI and at UMMS learned much from each other that we can apply in future projects.
